title: Cybersecurity scam of the week: Deepfake Impersonation Scams
description: AI-powered deepfake scams are targeting educational institutions and workplaces. These scams involve highly convincing fake videos or audio mimicking trusted figures, such as university leaders, HR personnel, or government officials, to deceive recipients.Recent examples include a fake CEO video generated with AI requesting fund transfers, a voice call urging staff to install malware disguised as a “security patch,” and fraudulent scholarship offers delivered via deepfake videos.Always verify unusual requests using a separate communication method, even if the sender seems familiar.Be wary of urgent or secretive messages—these are common red flags in scams.Never share passwords, credentials, or financial information without confirming the request.Visual or audio content alone cannot be trusted—always question and verify.

title: Brains aren't just for finals - join our brain function study!
description: NYUAD's Center for Brain and Health invites you to participate in a MRI study here on campus! title: Cybersecurity scam of the week: Deepfake Impersonation Scams
description: Cybercriminals are now using AI to create convincing voice or video calls that appear to come from senior government officials or organizational leadership.These deepfakes aim to build trust quickly, often urging a switch to another messaging app or take action.The next step typically involves sending a link, falsely presented as access to a new application, but in reality designed to compromise data or install malicious software. In some cases, scammers even pose as senior organizational staff, attempting to manipulate actions that could put institutional security at risk.Tips to Protect Yourself:Be cautious if someone claiming authority wants to move a conversation to another platform, especially if links are involved.Do not click on unfamiliar links. They may be malicious, harvesting personal data or installing harmful software.Watch for urgency or unusual requests from supposed officials, leadership, or family members. When in doubt, verify through official or alternate channels.Stay aware—AI makes faking identity easier than ever.

title: New water bottle filling stations
description: Dear Members of the NYU Abu Dhabi Community,As part of NYUAD’s ongoing commitment to sustainability and reducing single-use plastic consumption on campus, we are pleased to inform you that new water bottle filling stations have been installed at the following locations:A1 C Building - Level 02A2 C Building - Level 02A3 Building - Level 02A4 Building - Level 02A5 C Building - Level 02A6 C Building - Level 02C2 Building – Near Performance Gym Area (East side)These stations are now fully operational and are intended to encourage the use of reusable water bottles among students, staff, and visitors.We appreciate your support in helping NYUAD achieve its sustainability goals. Should you encounter any issues with the stations or require further information, please contact the Facilities Helpdesk at nyuad.facilities@nyu.edu or +971 2 628 8888 (option 03).Thank you for your cooperation.Campus Planning & Facilities Management

title: Updated Schedule for Temporary Relocation of the Welcome Center
description: Dear Members of the NYU Abu Dhabi Community,Further to our earlier notice regarding the relocation of the Welcome Center from 12th May 2025, please be informed that the schedule has been revised. The Welcome Center, will continue to operate from its original location between17th and 23rd May 2025to support Commencement activities.Subsequently, from24th May until 30th June 2025, the Welcome Center will be temporarily relocated to the Art Gallery Reading Room, within the same building, to facilitate renovation works.Signage will be placed at both the current and temporary locations to guide visitors accordingly.For any questions, please contact the Facilities Helpdesk at nyuad.facilities@nyu.edu or +971 2 628 8888 (option 03).We appreciate your understanding and cooperation.

title: Northsite Closed From May 7- August 24

title: Summer Scholars Program - Deadline to Apply this Friday, May 16!
description: Application Deadline: Friday, May 16th, 2025Interested in developing your writing, or a related project, over the summer?The Summer Scholars Program (SSP) offers specialized Writing Partnerships over the summer — from anywhere in the world. Students can propose any writing-related project to work on, including academic writing, creative projects, capstone development, and application materials (for graduate school, scholarships, internships, etc.).Participating students will be paired with an NYUAD Writing Instructor, design their own goals and workflow, and meet on Zoom/in-person forseven-ten(or an agreed equivalent) regularly scheduled sessions over the course of the summer term and/or summer break.Program Dates: May 26th - August 14th (dates may vary)To apply,please fill out this form.Questions? Emailnyuad.writingcenter@nyu.edu.
